title: Staging National Abjection: Theatre and Politics in Turkey and Its Diasporas
descriptions:

Title: Staging National Abjection: Theatre and Politics in Turkey and Its Diasporas

This transdisciplinary research project examines the complex relationships between theatre, politics, and national identity in Turkey and its diasporas from the mid-nineteenth century to contemporary productions. Through a combination of theoretical and ethnographic research methods, this study will investigate how theatre reflects and shapes the politics of belonging in Turkey and its diasporic communities. Five case studies will be conducted, focusing on theatre productions that involve Armenians after the Genocide, queer dramas, Islamic theatre, Sephardic Jewish theatre, and Alevi theatre.

The research objectives are to: (1) analyze the role of theatre in constituting 'the Turkish nation' and its Others; (2) provide insights into the political economy of contemporary Turkish theatre under a conservative neoliberal government; (3) critically examine the role of theatre in the politics of belonging in the nation-state; (4) explore the relationship between artistic performance and everyday citizenship; (5) advance understanding of diasporic and refugee theatre in Europe; and (6) offer insights into cultural politics in post-Imperial contexts and illiberal democracies.

This project will illustrate the political tensions that define Turkey and its growing diasporas, shedding light on the ways in which theatre reflects and challenges dominant narratives of national identity, belonging, and citizenship. The findings will contribute to a deeper understanding of the intersections between art, politics, and identity in Turkey and its diasporas, with implications for the study of theatre, politics, and cultural policy in diverse national and transnational contexts.
